title: Do typophiles have a good handwriting?
content:
Yes. As simple as that,  
Do typophiles have a good handwriting?  
Are you concerned with the meaning behind your handwriting and try to express something using it, or is it simply an uncontrollable aspect of you?
author: arch1k

To some point i believe handwriting can be a reflex of something, but i think it has more to do with pratice, dedication, context (and this is why i posted that image) and usefullness. Then it evolves, and becames an extension of your arm... so, it’s like drawing. This is what I think, it might be naive...

“i think it has more to do with pratice”
“Then it evolves, and becames an extension of your arm” …or it doesn’t, especially nowadays. When people don’t write by hand every day and all the time, I don’t really see how some “signal” of their personality (assuming there can be such a thing to begin with), in their handwriting, wouldn’t be drowned out by the noise caused by troubled technique, and lack of practice. Like, I know a bunch of people in computer jobs who all have similarly horrid, inconsistent, and illegible handwriting, while they’re vastly different people/characters. What unites them is, they don’t usually hand-write.

...and I guess when they _do_, it’s with a ballpoint, which isn’t going encourage calligraphic strokes...

I too am in the no camp.

In grade two, when we started to learn cursive writing instead of printing, mine was so bad that my teachers stopped asking me to try and just go back to printing. My dad printed in caps, and of course I wanted to be just like dad, so from then on, I printed in capital letters. After a while, (20 years) it got to a point that it was so messy that I couldn’t read my own notes half of the time.

I had always known about the [Bouma](http://web.archive.org/web/20090425144025/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bouma) model, so I decided to try an experiment.

So there I was, 20something years old, sitting on my deck in downtown Toronto with a stack of printouts with dashed lines on them and I literally practiced drawing a sheet of letter a’s, then b’s, then c”s… I did this for a little less than a week, and then simply forced myself to print in U&lc. It took about six months - one year to become comfortable with it, but once I had made the transition I noticed that I could go about 2x faster, have letters that were almost 2x messier, but due to the fact that I now had word-shapes that weren’t there when printing in all caps, I could read it 2x as easily. It’s still pretty bad though.

Even more interesting, the day following a seizure, my handwriting is bad beyond belief. If I’m not sure I’ve had a seizure in my sleep, my handwriting the next day is often a give-away. I’m sure there’s a PhD thesis in there somewhere.

I print in caps generally too.  
I read somewhere that Joseph Muller Brockmann was interested in graphology.

on a very basic, level I guess there is something to the concept of graphology - The perosn with a very tidy cursive who dots their i’s with little circles may have a different personallity than the person with hand writing that looks like it was done in total darkeness while he was blind drunk. Other than that... no.

Mine is like one of the above.

-=®=-
It is supposed to reveal something about the author’s personality rather than circumstance.

I’m not being sexist here, but i think dotting i’s with little circles is generally a teenage girly thing to do... or maybe little hearts... aaaah.

Nick Cooke

Heh. I actually still do the circle-tittle thing in my signature. But that’s because I ligate a lot, and if I do a normal tittle I’m going to ligate it to the following “n”, and then it looks like I’m called “nha”, or something. Not that anyone could read the top version…

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090425144025im_/http:/typophile.com/files/circletittle_6247.jpg)

Interesting topic, one I’ve always wondered about.

I pretty much learned to type so that others could read my writing. When I do write it is more of a shorthand notation. You could not understand the individual words without the greater context. I think I learned that from my dad. When I do try to slow down and write legibly it usually comes out mixEd cAsE and I tend to run out of room on the right side of the sheet.

And as far as content (like my graphic design) I usually need to spew it all out on the sheet then cut/paste/move it into some sort of logical order. Hard to do when it’s hand written.

...I’m glad I’m not the only one :-)

I guess I also “ligate” like Nina. Crossing T’s and dotting i’s can make a mess. And any letters that have similar adjacent strokes I sometimes merge together. The word “walk” would have w, a, l, and then I’d use the vertical from the l for the k. So if you didn’t know the context it would say “wak”. There are others, but I can’t think of them when I try.

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090425144025im_/http:/typophile.com/files/hand_5597.png)

To me it is like enjoyable exercise... and part of maintaining hand skills.

p.s. I never did pay attention to the lines : )

When it comes to my handwriting, my love of type begins to look like a matter of pure pragmatism.

My handwriting is heavily influenced by my mother’s, which could be described charitably as “EKG-like.” As a result, I tend to write in all caps to slow myself down and make the letter forms more distinct. Additionally, I’m a lefty, which adds a whole other layer of handwriting impediments.

I made a free font of my Dad’s handwriting, called Chemist:  
 [http://cathydavies.com/fonts.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090425144025/http:/cathydavies.com/fonts.html "http://cathydavies.com/fonts.html")

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090425144025im_/http:/typophile.com/files/chemist-specimen_3943.gif)

And, as an owner of several expensive coffee table tomes on Eric Gill, I’m certain he was a typophile.

He made some very unusual lettershapes, consistently. For example, lowercase e’s wth a distinct crescent shape, like an uncial e.

Has anyone out there admired their parents’/grandparents’ handwriting?

“graphology is to graphic design what phrenology is to neurology”

I’ve actually been gathering research and books on graphology. Neurology as well, but that’s another topic.

I run the risk of being stoned to death for supporting quackery, but mind you, handwriting analysis is respected in Europe, less so in the United States, and if for nothing provides an interesting and often times amusing take on letterforms from outside my profession.

Antiquated systems of interpretation and description have their merits in the over all scheme of everything. It wasn’t that long ago that designers were seriously trying to find the corresponding geometric shapes for the colors red, blue, and yellow.

Do you have this?

[http://www.amazon.com/Manual-Graphology-Eric-Singer/dp/0517616726](http://web.archive.org/web/20090425144025/http:/www.amazon.com/Manual-Graphology-Eric-Singer/dp/0517616726 "http://www.amazon.com/Manual-Graphology-Eric-Singer/dp/0517616726")

@ daniel\_poeira : That happens to you too?

My scribbly hand printing was the basis of nearly the second font I made, which I released for free and of those early works is the most popular. Even had requests for embedding licenses, and seen it pop up places I wasn’t told about.

Working on polishing it up with an expanded character set for a pay release.

Nick, I do have that book, although I cannot say I have read through it.

I have a whole stack of graphology books waiting for a rainy weekend, but the one that gives a nice general historical view of the differing schools of graphology is the recently published The Definitive Book of Handwriting Analysis: The Complete Guide to Interpreting Personalities, Detecting Forgeries, and Revealing Brain Activity through the Science of Graphology by Marc Seifer.

I cringe at the words Definitive, Complete, and Science in the title.

No, I am not a new age freak burning scented candles in my isolation room.

I have brutal handwriting, and my notes, usually hand-printed, are even worse. I will say that I developed some interesting ligatures; ing looks kind of like a yogh from a mediaeval manuscript. But yeah.
